article:
'', a cross whose limbs are slanted]] A 'cross' is a geometrical figure
consisting of two lines or bars perpendicular to each other, dividing one or two
of the lines in half. The lines usually run vertically and horizontally; if they
run obliquely, the design is technically termed a saltire, although the arms of
a saltire need not meet at right angles.

The cross is one of the most ancient human symbols, and has been used by many
religions, most notably Christianity. It is frequently a representation of the
division of the world into four elements (Chevalier, 1997) or cardinal points,
or alternately as the union of the concepts of divinity, the vertical line, and
the world, the horizontal line (Koch, 1955).
